unnormalised: I remember being totally stumped by Linear Algebra back in my engineering days at IIT Delhi. Prof. Sharma was explaining something about eigenvectors and eigenvalues, and all I could think was, "Yeh kya ho raha hai?!" It felt like a completely different language. My marks in the 1st quiz were embarrassingly low - a 6/20!
normalised: I remember being totally stumped by Linear Algebra back in my engineering days at I-I-T Delhi. Professor Sharma was explaining something about eigenvectors and eigenvalues, and all I could think was, "Yeh kya ho raha hai?!" It felt like a completely different language. My marks in the first quiz were embarrassingly low - a six divided by twenty!

unnormalised: What really helped me, though, was focusing on the practical applications. Instead of just memorizing formulas, I started trying to understand *why* these concepts mattered. For example, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) uses eigenvectors to reduce the dimensionality of data. Think about it: image compression! That's linear algebra in action. I spent hours on sites like Khan Academy and MIT OpenCourseWare, watching videos that broke down the complex math into bite-sized pieces. I even found a cool visualizer that showed how matrix multiplication transforms vectors in real-time - really helped my intuition.
normalised: What really helped me, though, was focusing on the practical applications. Instead of just memorizing formulas, I started trying to understand why these concepts mattered. For example, Principal Component Analysis (P-C-A) uses eigenvectors to reduce the dimensionality of data. Think about it: image compression! That's linear algebra in action. I spent hours on sites like Khan Academy and M-I-T OpenCourseWare, watching videos that broke down the complex math into bite-sized pieces. I even found a cool visualizer that showed how matrix multiplication transforms vectors in real-time - really helped my intuition.

unnormalised: Then, I started working through tons of problems. Not just the textbook ones, but also problems from old GATE exams (which, BTW, are a great resource). The more I practiced, the more the concepts started to click. I realized that things like determinants and matrix inverses are just tools for solving systems of equations. Solve 100 sums and suddenly the mists clear. My midterm score jumped to 17/20!

The more I practiced, the more the concepts started to click. I realized that things like determinants and matrix inverses are just tools for solving systems of equations. Solve one hundred sums and suddenly the mists clear. My midterm score jumped to seventeen divided by twenty!

unnormalised: Eventually, Linear Algebra went from being my nemesis to one of my favorite subjects. It's all about seeing the connections and understanding the underlying principles. If I can give one piece of advice, it's this: Don't give up! Keep practicing, keep asking questions, and you'll get there. And remember, even Prof. Sharma started somewhere. You got this!
